Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story:
I woke up early, determined to make it to the construction site on time. As a carpenter, I know how important it is to follow safety protocols—being late means rushing, and rushing leads to mistakes. My supervisor always reminds us that one careless move can cause an accident. I hurried through the city streets, toolbox in hand, when I stumbled upon a crowd gathered for a demonstration. The street was blocked by police barricades, and the only way to the site was straight through the restricted area.

A fellow protester caught my eye and urged me to step past the barricade, insisting it was our right to stand up for justice. But as a citizen, I know the law is clear: respect public property and the boundaries set for everyone’s safety. My heart pounded. If I waited, I’d be late and risk the safety of my coworkers. If I crossed, I’d be breaking the law and disrespecting the city I care about. I stood at the edge of the barricade, torn between my duty as a careful carpenter and my responsibility as a law-abiding citizen, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
